I really like JTest's coding standards enforcer feature. It's a reasonable substitute for communication and agreement in organizations where people don't like to talk to one another or organizations which a decision is reached that everyone ignores.

Other than that, I haven't found a good spot for JTest that other tools don't already fill. That's my fault: I had the chance to try it out in the summer and I was too lazy to do it. If anyone from Parasoft is reading this, I apologize for not giving your tool the time it deserves.

Still, based on what I've seen, JTest supports a kind of testing I don't do.

Take care.

So said Ilja Preuss on 4/4/2003 --------------------
> How does Jtest work? 

I think "How well does JTest work" would be a much more interesting
question. And IMO it can only be answered by trying it.

So, please try it for a reasonable time (say, half a year) - and try
Junit for a similiar amount of time. If you *then* report back here with
your experiences, you will probably find a very interested audience.

Until then, all your points are mere speculation - and not very
interesting ones, to actual practitioners.

Regards, Ilja

PS: Personally, I am not very inclined trying out Jtest - simply because
I *like* working test-driven. YMMV.
